fields.headline: Gordon's tonic
fields.bodyText: Gordon Brown (Comment, July 8) says "liberty, tolerance, fair play ... are the core values of Britishness". What tosh. The first lesson of Labour history is that every reform was wrestled from a reactionary ruling class - the right to belong to a union, the right to vote, votes for women etc. Has Gordon never heard of the Tolpuddle Martyrs, the Chartists or the suffragettes? Richard Knights Liverpool Gordon Brown's "golden thread" clearly has not reached Middlesbrough (Every moment for me is fear, July 8, same page). Kamwaura Nygothi and other victims of daily racial abuse must be wondering where this land of "tolerance" exists outside the idealised imaginations of some politicians. Richard Cullen Canterbury, Kent One of the threads through British history that Gordon Brown forgets is racism. A Sivanandan Institute of Race Relations Ashok Kumar (Letters, July 9) says Middlesbrough has never had intercommunal strife. He is evidently unaware of the so-called Cannon Street riots of the mid-60s. Michael McLoughlin Wigan, Lancs Peter Hall (Letters, July 8), who believes smacking teaches right from wrong, clearly doesn't know right from wrong himself. It is as wrong to hit children as it is to hit anyone else. More wrong, because hitting children teaches them hitting is OK. Which it isn't, as children soon find out when they try hitting people after the age of 16. Louisa Young London Will Ken Livingstone ask competitors in his proposed formula one race to pay the congestion charge (F1 drivers burn rubber, July 7)? Christopher Hawtree Hove, E Sussex
